alt_statements.statement: As someone who cares deeply about building inclusive, healthy school communities, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t be a shield for targeted hate that threatens or dehumanizes others. In the same way we set rules to keep our classrooms safe, our laws should limit speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups, while still allowing people to discuss and even criticize ideas, institutions, and policies.

As a journalist and a liberal, I’m deeply committed to the principle of free speech, including speech I find offensive, because open debate is essential to a functioning democracy. But as a Catholic and someone who sees how rhetoric can fuel real-world harm, I believe there must be firm legal limits when hate speech directly incites violence, harassment, or clear discrimination against protected groups. The line, to me, is crossed when words cease to be part of an argument—however ugly—and become tools to intimidate, dehumanize, or mobilize others to cause concrete harm.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime working to protect both people and the land, I think free speech is vital, but it shouldn’t be a shield for words that directly incite violence or dehumanize others. Hate speech that clearly targets groups in a way that encourages harm or strips them of their dignity poisons our common home, much like dumping toxins in a river. Within those limits, people should be free to say even unpopular things, but once speech becomes a tool to intimidate and terrorize, the law and the community have a duty to step in. That balance respects human dignity, fits my Catholic faith, and keeps our public life from turning into a dumping ground for hatred.

I think free speech has to stay as wide open as possible, even when it comes to hate speech, because once the government starts deciding what you can and can’t say, it’s a short trip to shutting down political dissent too. That said, I’m fine with limits where speech directly and specifically calls for violence or clearly threatens someone’s safety, because that crosses the line from expressing an ugly opinion into actual harm.

Free speech matters a lot to me, but I don’t think it should be a shield for people who are actively trying to dehumanize or threaten others. When hateful rhetoric crosses the line into incitement, harassment, or clear harm—especially against vulnerable groups—it should be restricted, much like we already restrict things like threats or defamation. We can protect robust debate, even uncomfortable or offensive ideas, without giving a free pass to speech that clearly endangers people’s safety and dignity.

As someone who came to this country from Mexico and is raising kids here, I believe strongly in free speech, but I also know what it feels like to hear words used to dehumanize people like me. I think there should be limits when speech is clearly meant to incite violence or harassment against a group, because that doesn’t just express an opinion—it puts people in danger and poisons the community. My faith teaches me that our words should build others up, not tear them down, and as a mother I want my children to grow up in a country where they are protected both by laws and by basic human decency.

As someone who’s grown up in a diverse, Hispanic community and cares a lot about people feeling safe and respected, I think free speech is really important, but it shouldn’t protect speech that directly threatens or dehumanizes others. Hate speech that encourages violence or clearly targets people for who they are crosses a line, because it doesn’t just express an opinion—it creates fear and can lead to real harm. I believe we should still allow uncomfortable or unpopular ideas, but when words become weapons used to bully, intimidate, or incite attacks on marginalized groups, there should be legal and social consequences.

Free speech is a core value to me, and I’m wary of the government deciding which opinions people are allowed to express, even if those opinions are ugly. That said, I think there should be limits when speech crosses into direct threats, clear incitement to violence, or targeted harassment that makes it unsafe for someone to live or work in peace. We should counter hateful ideas primarily with better arguments, strong communities, and teaching our kids right from wrong, not with broad censorship that could be turned against people with traditional or conservative views.

I believe free speech is a core American value and must be strongly protected, even when the words are ugly or offensive. That said, speech that directly incites violence or makes credible threats against individuals or groups should be limited by law, because we have a responsibility to keep our communities safe. As a Christian, I also feel that while people have the legal right to say hateful things, we have a moral duty to challenge that speech with truth, civility, and compassion rather than try to silence it.

As someone who works in a school kitchen and is raising little kids, I think free speech is crucial, but it shouldn’t be a shield for targeted hate that puts people—especially children and vulnerable groups—in danger. We should protect people’s right to express unpopular or controversial opinions, but draw a firm legal line when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against others. My Cherokee background and my faith both teach me the value of human dignity, so I believe society has a responsibility to limit hate speech that dehumanizes and harms communities while still preserving robust debate and criticism.

I believe free speech is a core American value and should be protected, even when it’s ugly or offensive, because once the government starts deciding what counts as “hate,” it can easily go too far. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against a person or group crosses the line and should be illegal, since that’s no longer just words—it’s putting people in real danger.

Coming from an Apache background and a Catholic faith that both teach respect and human dignity, I think free speech should be protected, but not when it is used to dehumanize or incite violence against others. Hate speech that targets people for who they are—especially groups that have already suffered discrimination—crosses a line and harms the peace and equality I believe in. Laws and community rules should stop speech that clearly encourages harm, while still allowing people to express different opinions without fear.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that hurt or scare others because it can make kids and families feel unsafe or like they don’t belong. At church and at school we’re told to treat others how we want to be treated, so I think free speech is important, but it should stop when it turns into hate that bullies or targets people for who they are.

As someone who believes deeply in both justice and dignity, I think free speech should be protected broadly, but not when it becomes a weapon used to dehumanize or incite violence against others. Hate speech that directly targets people for who they are—whether by race, religion, gender, or identity—does real damage, like graffiti carved into a community’s soul, and I believe that kind of speech should face legal limits and clear consequences. We can still allow tough, even uncomfortable debate, but drawing a line at harassment, threats, and incitement is essential to protecting the vulnerable and building a fairer, more compassionate society.

As someone who’s spent a career teaching young people and now volunteers in my community, I think free speech is essential to a healthy democracy, but it shouldn’t be a shield for targeted harassment or incitement to violence. Hate speech that directly threatens or dehumanizes people—especially along lines of race, religion, or identity—undermines the dignity and safety of our neighbors and should face legal limits. We can protect robust debate and even offensive opinions while drawing a clear line at speech that’s intended to intimidate, terrorize, or provoke real-world harm.

As someone who’s deeply involved in my community and raising young kids, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t be a shield for language that directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against others. Hate speech that creates a hostile or dangerous environment for people because of their race, religion, or identity crosses the line from expression into harm, and I think the law and platforms should step in at that point. At the same time, we need to protect space for tough, uncomfortable conversations about race, politics, and religion—just not for speech that’s clearly aimed at dehumanizing or endangering people.

I think free speech should be protected very strongly, even when it comes to offensive or hateful opinions, because once the government starts deciding what you can’t say, it’s easy for that power to be abused. That said, there should be clear limits where speech directly calls for violence or targets specific people with threats or harassment. As a Catholic, I believe everyone has dignity, but I don’t trust the government to be the one policing what’s “hate” and what’s just an unpopular or controversial view.

At my age, I’ve seen how ugly words can fuel real harm, and I don’t think we should pretend hate speech is just “another opinion.” I support strong free speech protections for criticism, protest, and even offensive art, but when speech directly targets people as less than human or encourages violence and discrimination, there ought to be legal and social limits. As a painter, I know expression matters, but so does the safety and dignity of the communities we live in.

I believe free speech is one of our most important rights, and we should be very careful about letting the government decide what people can and can’t say, even when it’s ugly. That said, when speech directly threatens or incites violence against a group of people, or clearly creates a dangerous environment—like encouraging harassment or attacks—I think that crosses a line where the law and community standards should step in.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, but they shouldn’t be allowed to say things that clearly encourage hurting or bullying other people because of who they are. At my school we get in trouble for name-calling and mean jokes, and I feel like that should count in the bigger world too, especially if it makes people feel unsafe or scared.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, even if it’s unpopular, but straight-up hate speech that targets people for their race, religion, or who they are should have limits, especially when it could lead to violence or bullying. As someone who’s mixed, I’ve seen how words can really mess people up, and I don’t think “free speech” should be an excuse to make others feel unsafe or less human.

As someone who values both the Constitution and personal responsibility, I believe free speech should be very broadly protected, even when it comes to offensive or hateful views. However, speech that directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or explicitly calls for the harm of individuals or groups crosses a line and should be restricted. We don’t need the government policing every ugly opinion, but we do need clear limits where words are being used as tools of intimidation or violence rather than expression.

Coming from an immigrant Mexican family and seeing how words can be used to dehumanize people like me or my comunidad, I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it crosses into direct threats, harassment, or calls for violence. Hate speech that clearly targets people for who they are and puts them in danger shouldn’t be treated like just another opinion; there should be legal and social consequences. At the same time, we have to be careful not to use “hate speech” as an excuse to shut down uncomfortable but honest debates about race, immigration, or politics.

As a lawyer and a Christian, I place a very high value on free speech, but I don’t believe it’s absolute—especially when words are weaponized to incite violence or dehumanize whole groups of people. The law should draw a firm line at direct incitement, targeted harassment, and credible threats, while otherwise protecting even offensive ideas, and we as a society should use education and counterspeech—not censorship—as our primary tools against bigotry.

As someone who grew up in New York and works in entertainment, I’m all about people expressing themselves freely, even if I don’t like what they’re saying—but hate speech is where I draw the line. Once your words are directly demeaning or inciting harm toward a protected group, they stop being “just opinions” and start creating a hostile, dangerous environment, especially for marginalized communities. I think the law should protect free speech up to the point where it becomes targeted harassment, credible threats, or organized incitement, and after that, there should be real consequences.

I believe free speech is a core American value and should be protected, even when the words are ugly or offensive, because once the government starts deciding which opinions are allowed, none of us are truly safe. That said, I support clear limits when speech directly incites violence or makes specific threats against people, because that crosses the line from expressing an opinion to endangering others.

I believe free speech is one of our most important rights, and we should be very cautious about putting limits on it, even when it comes to ugly or hateful opinions. Once the government starts deciding which words or ideas are allowed, it can be used to silence people for political reasons, and that worries me. That said, I think speech that directly threatens or incites violence against specific people or groups should be restricted and punished, because that crosses the line from opinion into real harm.

As someone who treats patients from every background and has seen how words can deepen psychological wounds, I believe free speech should be robust but not absolute. Hate speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or clear, targeted discrimination should be restricted, because it can quickly translate into real harm—much like an untreated infection spreading through a community. My faith and humanitarian values push me to defend dignity and safety for vulnerable groups, even as I remain wary of giving the state too much power to police mere offense or unpopular opinions.

I think people should be allowed to speak their minds, but once words turn into threats or make others feel actually unsafe, that’s going too far. Hate speech that targets people for things like their race, religion, or who they are should have limits, because it can spread violence and make it harder for everyone to live together in peace and equality.

I think people should be allowed to share their opinions, even if others disagree, but hate speech that threatens or targets people for who they are should be stopped. As a Christian, I believe we’re supposed to treat others with love and respect, so speech that encourages violence or bullying crosses a line. We can still protect free speech while having rules at school, online, and in public so that everyone feels safe and included.

As someone who works every day with vulnerable patients and sees how words can literally affect a person’s ability to participate in their own life, I believe free speech should stop where it intentionally dehumanizes or incites harm against others. We absolutely need robust protection for dissent and even uncomfortable opinions, but targeted hate speech that encourages discrimination or violence erodes community health just as surely as any physical threat. A healthy society is like a healthy body—if we allow toxic elements to spread unchecked, everything else suffers—so I support legal limits on speech that actively endangers people’s safety or access to equal participation in public life.

As a teacher and a mom, I believe free speech is vital in a democracy, but it can’t be a shield for language that directly threatens or dehumanizes others. Hate speech that incites violence, targets children, or creates a hostile environment in schools or public spaces should face clear legal and institutional limits. We should still allow difficult, even uncomfortable conversations about controversial issues, but not tolerate speech that systematically undermines the safety and dignity of marginalized people. Protecting people—especially kids—from harm has to take priority over protecting someone’s “right” to abuse others.

I think free speech is really important, but I don’t believe it should protect direct, targeted hate that clearly threatens or dehumanizes people. You should absolutely be allowed to voice unpopular or uncomfortable opinions, but when speech turns into incitement or creates a hostile environment where certain groups don’t feel safe existing in public, that crosses a line. As someone who interacts with all kinds of people at work every day, I’ve seen how words can either build community or poison it, and I think the law should draw the line at protecting people’s safety and basic dignity, not protecting cruelty.

I believe free speech is one of our most important rights, and we have to be very careful about letting the government decide what counts as “hate” because that can slide into punishing people just for having unpopular opinions. That said, I do think there should be limits when speech directly incites violence, makes specific threats, or clearly targets people in a way that could lead to real harm. As a Catholic, I think we’re called to treat others with dignity, so I’d rather see hateful views challenged and countered in open debate and through community standards than banned outright by the state.

As a teacher and a Catholic, I believe words carry real power and responsibility, so there should be limits on speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or clear discrimination against specific groups. We need to protect open dialogue, including unpopular opinions, but when “speech” becomes a tool to terrorize or dehumanize others, especially vulnerable students or communities, it crosses a line. A healthy democracy can and should draw that boundary, while still safeguarding robust, respectful debate on difficult issues.

At my age, I’ve seen how words can either knit communities together or tear them apart, and hate speech reliably does the latter. I believe the law should protect the broadest possible range of political and personal expression, but draw a firm line where speech directly incites violence, harassment, or systemic discrimination against vulnerable groups. The First Amendment isn’t a license to terrorize people in their own neighborhoods or workplaces; it’s a commitment to a shared public space where everyone can participate without fear.

I believe free speech is a foundational American value and should be strongly protected, even when it’s offensive or unpopular, because once the government starts deciding which ideas are allowed, everyone’s freedoms are at risk. That said, I support limits where speech directly incites violence, makes true threats, or actively targets and harasses individuals, because protecting public safety and basic human dignity is also a moral responsibility.

As a Christian and a counselor, I believe words have real power to wound or to heal, so I don’t think hate speech should be treated as harmless “just opinions.” The law should strongly protect dissenting and even offensive ideas, but it should limit speech that directly dehumanizes or incites violence against people because of who they are—race, religion, sexual orientation, or other core identities. From my work with individuals and families, I’ve seen how persistent hateful rhetoric can create fear and trauma, especially in communities like my own, so we have a moral duty to draw a firm line where speech turns into a tool of intimidation and harm.

I think people should usually be allowed to say what they believe, but hate speech is different because it can seriously hurt others and even lead to violence. As a Christian and someone who cares about protecting the environment and our community, I don’t think we should tolerate speech that clearly targets and degrades people for things like their race, religion, or who they are. Free speech should stop where it starts to encourage real harm or discrimination against others.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, even if it’s unpopular, but hate speech that clearly targets a group and encourages violence or bullying should be limited. As someone who’s seen and heard racist jokes about Filipinos and other Asians, I know words can really hurt and make people feel unsafe, especially kids. I don’t think the government should control every rude comment, but schools, online platforms, and communities should have rules that stop speech that dehumanizes or threatens others. Free speech is important, but it shouldn’t be used as a weapon to destroy someone’s dignity or safety.

As an educator and a progressive, I believe free speech is a foundational democratic value, but it cannot be an absolute shield for speech that directly incites violence or intentionally dehumanizes others in ways that undermine their safety and ability to participate in public life. In a school context especially, we see how hate speech doesn’t just “express an opinion”; it creates a hostile environment that silences and harms marginalized students and staff. So while we should protect even unpopular or offensive ideas, we must draw firm legal and institutional lines against targeted harassment, calls for violence, and sustained, identity-based abuse. That’s not censorship of ideas—it’s a necessary boundary to ensure freedom and dignity for everyone, not just the loudest or most powerful.

As a public school teacher and a Christian, I value free speech deeply, but I also see every day how words can wound and isolate kids who are already vulnerable. I think speech that directly incites violence or harassment against a protected group should be restricted, and institutions—especially schools and public agencies—have a responsibility to set firm boundaries around hate speech. That’s not about silencing disagreement; it’s about protecting people’s basic dignity and safety so everyone can participate fully in our democracy.

As someone who believes in both free expression and basic respect, I think there should be reasonable limits on hate speech when it directly threatens or incites violence against specific groups. People should be able to voice unpopular opinions, but not in ways that put others in danger, create a climate of terror, or dehumanize them because of their race, religion, or identity. From my perspective, protecting human dignity and keeping our communities safe has to come before allowing speech that’s meant purely to harm.

Having lived through both subtle and open discrimination, I believe that speech which directly dehumanizes others or incites violence should not be protected as “free” in any meaningful moral sense. Words have karmic consequences; when they are used as tools to terrorize, silence, or exclude entire groups, they are already an act of harm, not just an opinion. However, restrictions should be clearly and narrowly defined in law to prevent abuse, focusing on intent and real-world impact, so that we still preserve space for uncomfortable but necessary dialogue about prejudice and power.

As someone who values both civil liberties and the real-world impact of words on people’s health and safety, I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not absolute. When “hate speech” directly incites violence, clearly targets and harasses specific individuals or groups, or creates a credible threat that they will be harmed or driven from public life, it crosses a line and should face legal limits. At the same time, offensive or bigoted opinions that don’t rise to that level should generally remain legal, and we should counter them through education, dialogue, and social accountability rather than censorship.

Free speech is one of the core freedoms I served to protect, and I’m very wary of the government deciding which opinions are allowed and which are not, even when it comes to so‑called “hate speech.” That said, speech that directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or targets individuals and groups for harassment that endangers their safety should be restricted and punished. We don’t need more speech codes and thought policing—what we need is to enforce existing laws, promote personal responsibility, and let bad ideas be defeated in the open, not driven underground.

I think free speech is essential, but it can’t be a shield for deliberately dehumanizing or inciting violence against others. As a mom and someone who cares deeply about community and the environment we share, I support limits on hate speech when it directly targets protected groups in ways that encourage harm, harassment, or discrimination. We can debate ideas passionately without tolerating speech that systematically undermines people’s basic safety and dignity.

My mommy and daddy say we should never say mean things that hurt people’s feelings, especially about how they look or where they’re from, because Jesus wants us to be kind and love everyone. I think people should be allowed to talk, but if someone is using words to make others feel scared or bad for who they are, then the grown‑ups should stop it.

I believe the First Amendment is one of our most important rights, and even ugly or offensive speech needs strong protection so the government doesn’t get to decide what we’re allowed to say. That said, speech that directly threatens violence, incites crimes, or clearly targets people for harm should be limited and punished. We should fight hate speech more through open debate, personal responsibility, and strong community values than through broad speech laws that can be abused.

My mom and dad tell me Jesus wants us to use kind words, not words that make people feel small or scared because of who they are. I think people should be able to say what they feel, but if words are used to hurt others on purpose or make them feel in danger, grown‑ups and rules should stop that. Words should help people feel loved and safe, not hated.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that hurt others on purpose, especially about how they look, talk, or where they come from. My parents and church teach me that God loves everyone and we should be kind, so words that make people feel scared or unsafe shouldn’t be okay. You can still say what you think, but not in a way that tries to make other people feel small or hated.

As someone who cares a lot about both my kids’ future and standing up for people with disabilities and other marginalized groups, I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it crosses into direct threats, targeted harassment, or incitement to violence. Hate speech that creates a climate where certain groups are afraid to exist openly doesn’t just “express an opinion”; it chips away at their basic safety and dignity. We should still allow tough, even uncomfortable conversations, but draw a firm legal line where speech is clearly intended to harm, intimidate, or dehumanize people based on who they are.

Growing up Black in Texas and spending my life teaching kids, I’ve seen firsthand how words can either build folks up or tear them down. I believe free speech is essential, but once it crosses into direct harassment, incitement to violence, or persistent dehumanization of a group, there ought to be legal limits and real consequences. That isn’t about silencing disagreement; it’s about protecting people’s basic dignity so everyone can participate in public life without being targeted. Free expression should be a shield for ideas, not a weapon used to terrorize communities.

My mamá says that Jesus wants us to be kind with our words, so I think people shouldn’t say really mean things that hurt others because of how they look or where they’re from. I’m little and still learning to talk, but when someone uses words to make people feel scared or bad, I think grown-ups should stop it, like a timeout for hurtful talking.

As someone who grew up in the South and watched the civil rights movement unfold, I believe very strongly in free speech, but I also know words can be used like weapons against people who’ve already had more than enough aimed at them. I think the law should step in when speech directly incites violence or intentionally terrorizes people because of their race, religion, or identity, but not to police every ugly opinion. We should answer most hateful speech with better speech, education, and firm social consequences, while keeping clear legal boundaries around threats and organized harassment.

As someone who came to this country from Vietnam and built a life and career here, I value free speech deeply, especially because it protects minority voices like mine. But I also think speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or credible threats against specific groups crosses a line and should be limited by law. Beyond that, I’d rather see hateful ideas confronted, debated, and disproven in the open than pushed underground, while institutions and communities set firm standards for respectful conduct.

As a mom, I think words really matter, especially when kids are listening and learning how to treat others. I believe people should be free to share their opinions, even unpopular ones, but when speech directly targets a group with threats, harassment, or intentionally stirs up violence or dehumanizes them, that crosses a line. As a Catholic, I’m taught that every person has dignity, so I support reasonable limits on hate speech that clearly protect people’s safety and humanity, while still allowing honest debate and disagreement.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, even if it’s unpopular, because free speech is important for learning and understanding different ideas. But I also think there should be limits when speech turns into direct hate or threats against a group of people, because that can really hurt others and make them feel unsafe. It’s one thing to argue about ideas, but it’s different when someone is trying to bully or encourage violence against people just because of who they are.

As someone who works every day to create a safe, nurturing environment for children, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t protect speech that directly incites violence or targets people with the intent to dehumanize and intimidate them. Kids absorb the messages around them, and when hate speech is allowed to flourish unchecked, it normalizes prejudice and undermines the values of inclusion and respect that we try so hard to teach. Thoughtful limits that focus on preventing harm—not silencing unpopular opinions—are, to me, consistent with both democratic values and the responsibility we have to protect vulnerable communities.

As someone who’s pretty liberal and values treating people with dignity, I think free speech is crucial, but it shouldn’t protect speech that directly incites violence or harassment against specific groups. Coming from a Catholic background, I still believe everyone is made in the image of God, so speech that dehumanizes people because of their race, religion, sexuality, or identity crosses a moral line. That said, I’d rather see limits focused on clear threats and targeted abuse than on just offensive or ignorant opinions, so we don’t end up shutting down necessary debate and education.

I believe free speech is a core American right, and we should be very cautious about letting the government decide which words are allowed and which are not, even when those words are ugly or hateful. At the same time, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against a person or group crosses a line and should be restricted, because everyone deserves basic safety and dignity.

I believe free speech is a fundamental right and a core American value, and I’m very wary of the government deciding what people can and can’t say, even when the words are ugly or hateful. That said, there should be clear limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or credible threats against specific people or groups. In my view, the best way to counter hate is through more speech—calling it out, standing firm in our own values, and teaching respect—rather than trying to censor it.

Como alguien que ha vivido muchos años y ha visto lo que el odio puede hacer en una comunidad, creo que la libertad de expresión es fundamental, pero no debe usarse como escudo para deshumanizar o incitar violencia contra otros. Las palabras pueden sembrar el mismo veneno que los actos, especialmente contra minorías y personas vulnerables, así que debe haber límites claros cuando el discurso promueve daño, discriminación activa o violencia. Podemos y debemos permitir opiniones fuertes y debates difíciles, pero como cristiano y como demócrata, pienso que nuestra responsabilidad moral es proteger la dignidad de cada persona por encima del “derecho” a propagar odio.

As someone who believes in both free expression and looking out for each other, I think hate speech shouldn’t be protected when it directly incites violence or creates a clearly hostile environment for targeted groups. In a diverse, service-focused world like restaurants, you see how words can make people feel unsafe or unwelcome really fast. I still want people to be able to criticize ideas, including religion or politics, but once it crosses into dehumanizing people for who they are, I think there should be legal and social limits.

I think people should be able to say a lot, even stuff I really disagree with, because shutting people up can get sketchy and unfair fast. But when “speech” turns into direct threats, harassment, or encouraging violence against a group—especially minorities—that’s where there need to be clear limits and consequences. Free speech shouldn’t be a shield for terrorizing people or making them feel unsafe just for who they are.

I think free speech is one of the core things that makes this country what it is, and we’ve got to be real careful about letting the government decide what people can and can’t say, even when it’s ugly. That said, once speech turns into direct threats, harassment, or clear incitement to violence against a group, that’s where the line should be drawn. People ought to be able to speak their minds, but they also need to take responsibility when their words are used to stir up real harm.

As someone who’s Black, liberal, and active in my church and community, I think free speech is crucial, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence or targets people in ways that make them unsafe where they live and work. Growing up seeing how words can fuel real-world hate, I believe we need clear legal limits on speech that crosses into threats, harassment, and organized dehumanization, while still allowing space for hard, even uncomfortable conversations about race, religion, and politics.

As a conservative and a teacher, I believe free speech is a core American value, and even offensive or unpopular opinions should generally be protected so long as they don’t incite violence or direct threats. At the same time, in a school setting and public life, I think we have a responsibility to set firm boundaries on speech that explicitly targets and dehumanizes individuals or groups, especially in ways that could reasonably lead to harassment or harm.

As someone who came to this country from Haiti and has seen how words can both dehumanize and liberate, I believe free speech must be strongly protected, but not idolized above people’s basic safety and dignity. Hate speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or clear discrimination should be restricted by law, and institutions—especially universities—have a moral obligation to draw firm lines against speech that targets people’s humanity while still allowing robust, even uncomfortable, debate.

As a teacher and someone who’s active in my community, I think free speech is essential, but it can’t be an excuse to openly dehumanize or incite harm against others. I support strong protections for speech, including unpopular opinions, but I also believe there should be legal limits on speech that directly threatens, harasses, or intentionally foments violence against marginalized groups.

As someone who has lived a long life and seen how words can either heal or harm, I believe free speech is essential to a healthy democracy, but it should not be an absolute license to dehumanize others. We should draw legal lines where speech directly incites violence, targeted harassment, or clear discrimination against protected groups, while still allowing people to express even very unpopular opinions. In a just and compassionate society, we have a moral obligation to protect vulnerable communities from being terrorized under the guise of “free expression,” without sliding into blanket censorship.

As someone who came to this country from Vietnam and values both freedom and community, I believe free speech is very important, but it should not protect clear hate speech that threatens or deliberately degrades people because of their race, religion, or identity. Words can create fear and division, and as a Catholic and a mother, I feel society has a responsibility to protect vulnerable groups, especially children, from that kind of harm. I support reasonable limits, like laws against incitement and harassment, while still allowing people to express different opinions respectfully.

As someone who’s pretty liberal and works with all kinds of people every day, I think free speech is crucial, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly threatens or targets people with violence or clear harassment. Hate speech that creates a hostile environment or is meant to intimidate specific groups crosses a line, especially for communities like mine that have dealt with discrimination. We should still allow people to express unpopular or offensive opinions, but when words become tools to dehumanize or incite harm, there should be legal and social consequences.

As someone who has spent a lifetime surrounded by books and young minds, I believe deeply in free speech, but I also believe that speech which directly incites violence or clearly targets and dehumanizes others crosses a line. Hate speech that creates a hostile, threatening environment—especially for children or vulnerable groups—should be limited by reasonable laws and firm community standards, much like we set rules in a library so everyone feels safe to learn. We don’t protect the freedom to shout fire in a crowded theater, and in the same spirit, we shouldn’t protect speech that is clearly meant to terrorize or strip others of their dignity.

As someone who grew up Catholic and still spends a lot of time volunteering in my community, I believe words have real power to either build people up or tear them down. I support strong free speech protections, but I also think we should draw a firm legal line where speech intentionally incites violence, harassment, or clear discrimination against marginalized groups. Calling that “hate speech” isn’t about silencing unpopular opinions; it’s about preventing real harm and protecting people’s safety and dignity. In a healthy democracy, you can criticize ideas all you want, but you shouldn’t have the right to use speech as a weapon to terrorize others.

Free speech is important, but I don’t think it should protect speech that directly targets and dehumanizes people based on who they are, especially when it encourages violence. In a busy kitchen with people from all kinds of backgrounds, you see how toxic and damaging that kind of talk can be to both mental health and teamwork. We should still allow harsh criticism of ideas, including religions and political beliefs, but when speech crosses into threats, harassment, or clear incitement against a group, there should be legal and social consequences. Protecting people from that kind of hate is part of building a healthier, more sustainable society—just like protecting the environment.

As someone who cares a lot about my kids’ future and grew up learning Catholic values about human dignity, I think free speech is crucial, but it shouldn’t protect speech that directly dehumanizes people or incites violence against them. I don’t want my children growing up in a country where people can openly spread hatred that makes others feel unsafe at school, work, or in our neighborhood. We should still allow tough, even offensive political debate, but draw a firm legal line at targeted harassment, threats, and organized hate meant to intimidate or harm others.

Coming from China, I’ve seen how governments can abuse “protecting harmony” as an excuse to silence people, so I’m very cautious about limiting speech. But as a Catholic and a mom raising kids in this country, I also believe words can do real harm, especially when they target people for their race, religion, or identity and encourage violence. I think the law should clearly restrict hate speech that directly incites harm, harassment, or discrimination, while still protecting people’s right to express unpopular or offensive opinions. The focus should be on preventing concrete damage to people’s safety and dignity, not on policing every hurt feeling.

My mom says Jesus wants us to be kind with our words, so I think people shouldn’t say really mean things that hurt others on purpose. It’s okay to disagree or be upset, but calling people bad names because of how they look or where they’re from should not be allowed. Words can make people feel very sad and scared, so grown‑ups should stop that kind of talking.

I believe free speech is one of our most important rights, and we should be very careful about letting the government decide what people are allowed to say, even if it’s ugly or hateful. That said, when speech turns into direct threats, targeted harassment, or calls for violence against a person or group, that crosses a line and should be limited by law.

I believe free speech is a core American value and should be protected very strongly, even for views we don’t like, because once the government starts deciding what can’t be said, it’s easy for that power to be abused. That said, speech that directly incites violence, makes true threats, or clearly targets individuals for harassment should be limited, because that crosses the line from expression into harm. As a conservative and a Catholic, I think we should fight hateful ideas with better ideas, strong community values, and moral leadership—not with broad speech laws that could end up silencing people for their beliefs.

As someone who values both the Constitution and basic human decency, I believe free speech must be strongly protected, even when it offends, but not when it directly incites violence or clear harm against others. Hate speech that crosses the line into threats, targeted harassment, or actively encouraging violence should be restricted, because it endangers the safety and dignity of people made in the image of God. At the same time, we should be very cautious about letting the government broadly define and police “hate,” because that can easily turn into silencing unpopular opinions rather than truly dangerous behavior.

As someone who’s seen a lot of social change over the decades and values both fairness and open dialogue, I believe free speech should be protected up to the point where it directly incites violence, harassment, or clear discrimination against a targeted group. Hate speech that explicitly encourages harm or creates an environment where people are realistically afraid to live, work, or worship should face legal limits, because that goes beyond expression and becomes a tool of oppression. At the same time, I think we should be careful not to label every offensive or ignorant statement as “hate speech,” so that we can still challenge bad ideas openly and educate people rather than simply silence them.

As someone who cares deeply about both civil liberties and community well‑being, I believe free speech should be robustly protected, but it shouldn’t be a shield for direct, targeted hate that endangers people. When speech crosses the line into harassment, incitement to violence, or deliberate efforts to dehumanize and intimidate marginalized groups, society has a responsibility to set legal and social limits. We can and should allow offensive, even ugly opinions, but we don’t have to tolerate speech that is weaponized to strip others of their safety and dignity.

As someone who spent her career protecting public health and the environment, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence or systematically dehumanizes vulnerable groups. Hate speech that targets people based on race, religion, gender, or similar traits and creates a climate of fear and real harm should face legal limits, much like we already limit speech that endangers public safety. At the same time, we need to safeguard robust political debate and uncomfortable conversations, because confronting prejudice openly is often the best way to challenge it.

As a Muslim and an immigrant, I know words can wound deeply and even create fear, so truly dangerous hate speech that directly incites violence or targeted harassment should be limited by law. But people should still be free to criticize beliefs, cultures, and even religions, as long as they do it without calling for harm. In my view, the line should be drawn where speech moves from strong opinion to a real threat to safety and social order, because stability and respect are more important than absolute freedom to insult others.

Coming from El Salvador and being part of a Native community here, I’ve seen how hateful language can turn into real discrimination and even violence, so I don’t think “free speech” should protect direct calls for harm or serious harassment against people because of who they are. I support strong protections for criticizing governments, companies, and ideas, but once speech is clearly inciting violence or systematic abuse against a group, the law should step in. Free speech shouldn’t be a shield for terrorizing people or making them feel unsafe just for existing.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees firsthand how words can either build trust or cause real harm, I believe free speech should be strongly protected but not absolute—there must be limits when it crosses into direct incitement of violence, targeted harassment, or deliberate attempts to dehumanize groups. Hate speech that creates a climate of fear and undermines people’s ability to participate safely in public life doesn’t just express an opinion; it erodes the very equality and dignity that a free society depends on.

As someone who came to this country, built a small gift shop from nothing, and found a home in both the Korean and Jewish communities, I believe deeply in free speech—but also in our responsibility to protect people from dehumanizing hate. Speech that criticizes ideas, policies, or beliefs should be protected, even if it’s uncomfortable, but speech that directly incites violence or targets people as less than human because of their race, religion, gender, or identity crosses a line. In a diverse, democratic society, we need clear legal limits on incitement and harassment, along with strong social norms that make it clear hate has no place in our public life.

La libertad de expresión es importante, pero no debe ser una excusa para deshumanizar a otros o incitar a la violencia. Uno puede tener opiniones fuertes y decir verdades incómodas, pero cuando las palabras se usan para promover odio o atacar a personas por su raza, religión o nacionalidad, allí se debe poner un límite. Yo he sentido en carne propia cómo duele ese tipo de discurso, y sé que no construye nada bueno para nuestras familias ni para la comunidad.

As someone who came to this country, became a citizen, and works face‑to‑face with all kinds of people every day, I value free speech deeply—but I’ve also seen how hateful words can make people feel unsafe and unwelcome. I think the law should protect almost all speech, but there should be clear limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against specific groups. Within that boundary, we should counter hate speech not just with more speech, but with community standards in workplaces, schools, and online spaces that don’t tolerate demeaning others for who they are.

I think free speech is really important, but hate speech that targets people for things like their race, religion, or who they are should have limits, especially if it encourages violence or bullying. Words can hurt people and make them feel unsafe, and that’s not fair or equal. People should be allowed to share their opinions, but not in ways that dehumanize others or make it harder for them to live their lives safely.

Free speech is fundamental, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence or targets people in ways that clearly endanger their safety and ability to live freely. I support strong protections for expression, even when it’s offensive, but I think laws and platforms should draw a line at hate speech that explicitly promotes harm or discrimination against protected groups.

As someone deeply involved in community service and guided by my Christian faith and belief in social justice, I see free speech as a core democratic value—but not an absolute one. I believe there should be clear limits when speech directly incites violence, targets people with credible threats, or intentionally dehumanizes entire groups in ways that predictably lead to harm. We’ve seen how hate speech can tear at the social fabric and make marginalized neighbors feel unsafe in their own communities, and I can’t accept that as the price of freedom. Protecting vulnerable people from targeted hatred is, to me, fully consistent with protecting a robust, open marketplace of ideas.

I think free speech has to stay as wide open as possible, even when it comes to ugly, hateful stuff, because once you let the government decide what you can’t say, it’s real easy for that to get abused and used against anyone who’s unpopular. That said, speech that’s a direct, targeted threat or a clear call to violence should be off-limits, and private businesses, communities, and platforms should be free to set their own rules about what they’ll tolerate.

I think free speech is a bedrock American value, but it shouldn’t be a shield for people who are actively trying to threaten, terrorize, or dehumanize others. We ought to draw the legal line at direct incitement to violence and targeted harassment, while still allowing offensive or unpopular opinions so they can be challenged in the open. In a diverse country, we’ve got a responsibility to protect vulnerable communities from real harm without turning disagreement or rough language into a crime.

As someone who believes strongly in the Constitution and personal responsibility, I think free speech is a core American value that should be protected, even when it’s ugly or hateful. That said, when speech crosses the line into direct threats, harassment, or inciting violence against a person or group, the law should step in, because everyone is made in the image of God and deserves basic safety and dignity. I don’t think the government should police hurt feelings or unpopular opinions, but it should firmly punish speech that clearly aims to cause real, immediate harm.

As a libertarian and a veteran, I believe free speech—including speech most people find offensive—is a core liberty that government should restrict only in extremely narrow cases, like direct threats or incitement to imminent violence. Hate speech is ugly and corrosive, but the answer is social accountability, counter-speech, and community standards, not state censorship that can be weaponized against any unpopular group or belief.

I believe free speech is one of our most important rights, and we have to be very careful about giving the government power to decide what people can and can’t say, even if it’s hateful or offensive. That said, speech that directly threatens, harasses, or incites violence against specific people or groups should be restricted and punished, because that crosses the line from opinion into real harm.

As a teacher and someone who cares deeply about social justice, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t protect speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against marginalized groups. Hate speech that creates a hostile environment in schools or communities silences others and undermines their ability to participate equally in public life. We should set legal and institutional limits at the point where speech moves from expressing even ugly opinions into actively threatening people’s safety and dignity, while still allowing room for education, dialogue, and growth.
